RITONAVIR

PROTEASE INHIBITORS

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

HIV infection in combination with other antiretroviral drugs (high-dose ritonavir),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 300 mg every 12 hours for 3 days, increased in steps of 100 mg every 12 hours over not longer than 14 days; increased to 600 mg every 12 hours.

Low-dose booster to increase effect of other protease inhibitors,

By mouth

  • For adults
    100–200 mg 1–2 times a day.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid in decompensated liver disease; in severe impairment without decompensation, use ‘booster’ doses with caution (avoid treatment doses).

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Acne, anxiety, arthralgia, blood pressure changes, blurred vision, confusion, cough, decreased blood thyroxine concentration, fever, flushing, gastro-intestinal haemorrhage, menorrhagia, mouth ulcers, oedema, peripheral neuropathy, pharyngitis, renal impairment, seizures, syncope,

uncommon: Electrolyte disturbances, myocardial infarction,

rare: Toxic epidermal necrolysis,

Pancreatitis

Signs and symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis (including raised serum lipase) should be evaluated—discontinue if pancreatitis diagnosed.

Directions for administration

Bitter taste of oral solution can be masked by mixing with chocolate milk; do not mix with water, measuring cup must be dry.

Advice for patients and carers

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer ritonavir oral solution.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Cardiac conduction disorders
  • pancreatitis
  • structural heart disease

Prepared medicinal forms of RITONAVIR

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Tablet
Oral solution
